newsitem.title: UK: Most Irish face jokes, insults, jibes in Britain.
newsitem.headline: Most Irish face jokes, insults, jibes in Britain.

text.p: Most Irish people living in Britain have faced insults, hurtful jokes and intimidating behaviour because of their origins, the Commission for Racial Equality (CRE) said on Wednesday.
"Although only 20 percent reported a 'bad atmosphere' at work, 79 percent had been subjected to abusive and insulting anti-Irish jokes and remarks," the CRE said in a statement.
"The majority of those questioned could immediately identify instances of behaviour which they had found insulting, hurtful or intimidating."
The CRE urged employers to ensure their equal opportunity policies included people of Irish origin, who make up Britain's largest ethnic minority by immigration.
Irish-born and their children are estimated to form 4.6 percent of the population of Britain and 11.5 percent of the population of greater London.
Most of the Irish-born belong to the most deprived social classes and have lower than average rates of upward mobility and rates of car ownership well below average, said the CRE.
Male Irish unemployment in Britain is above average and their health in middle age below average.
Despite a long and large presence in Britain, especially in its inner cities, Irish immigrants often find themselves the butt of English jokes, stereotyped as ignorant and drink-sodden.
"Britain has been a place of welcome and opportunity for many Irish people," said the CRE. "Yet in spite of this visible integration, there is evidence of inequality, discrimination and prejudice."
The independent body said the increasingly positive attitudes in Britain towards Irish culture offered an opportunity for improved race relations.
